awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Ultimate Machine, Modeling neuromuscular control and musculoskeletal dynamics to improve human ability
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER grant focuses on the development and evaluation of novel computational tools to predict changes in human movement with exoskeletons. Recent technological advances have created new exoskeletons, external devices including orthoses and braces, which can apply passive or active torques to the human body. However, the ability of these devices to make consistent improvements in movement remains challenging. A fundamental knowledge gap exists in how the human body responds and adapts when wearing these devices, hindering performance and development. To overcome this gap, this research will use a combination of musculoskeletal simulation and experimental motion capture to create a conceptual framework for modeling and predicting changes in neuromuscular control and musculoskeletal dynamics when wearing devices that apply assistive, augmentive, or preventive torques to the human body. Two model systems that apply external torques to the ankle will be used to experimentally test and evaluate this framework: passive ankle foot orthoses for assisting movement and active ankle orthoses for enhancing power. These systems will be tested with individuals with stroke or cerebral palsy who commonly use orthoses to improve movement, as well as unimpaired individuals. Prior simulations of human movement have largely focused on the musculoskeletal system, but few techniques exist to model neuromuscular control and muscle recruitment. Dynamic simulation provides an ideal framework to specify and test different neuromuscular control strategies and expand our ability to design optimized exoskeletons. This research will develop algorithms to model neuromuscular control with dynamic simulation, predict changes in human movement with exoskeletons, and experimentally evaluate this new framework. All algorithms developed will be shared in an open-source simulation framework, OpenSim, for other researchers and educators to use.

The proposed research will provide the foundation to improve movement for individuals with neurological disorders, such as cerebral palsy and stroke, and others who can benefit from advances in wearable technology. The technical advances in algorithm development and neuromuscular simulation will provide a new set of tools for researchers and clinicians to use in the design, evaluation, and prescription of devices to enhance human movement. To help train engineers who can apply their knowledge to the complexities of the human body, a multidisciplinary education program focused on human engineering will be created at the University of Washington for students in engineering and medicine. Students will participate in journal clubs, coursework, and design projects where they will create open-source orthoses for individuals with disabilities. We will also develop open-source outreach modules focused on human engineering in partnership with local programs that encourage under-represented groups to pursue careers in engineering, including women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities. These modules will be shared on-line for other groups to use and help encourage a diverse community of future engineers. Together this work will help to accelerate the design and prescription of exoskeletons for individuals with neurological disorders and promote a community passionate about enhancing the performance of the ultimate machine - the human body.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER awarded supported integrated research, education, and outreach activities that sought to expand our understanding of how assistive technology can support and improve human movement. Specifically, we focused on how orthoses or exoskeletons - devices that can be worn on the body to augment an individual's movement - need to be customized based upon each individual's needs and abilities.

With respect to advancing knowledge, this research captured the complex changes in neuromuscular control and musculoskeletal dynamics that underlie individual responses to ankle exoskeletons. Even among nondisabled adults, each individual changes their muscle activity and walking patterns in different ways in response to exoskeleton properties. Predicting these responses is challenging, but important to support the design and customization of new devices. We demonstrated that physics-based modeling and data-driven approaches can help to improve predictions of individual responses and understand the causal mechanisms that drive these responses.

With respect to benefiting society, this knowledge will help to improve our design of assistive technology that can be easily customized to each individual to support their movement and activities of daily living. We tested these methods for customization of upper-extremity devices, such as wrist-driven orthoses for individuals with spinal cord injury, and lower-extremity devices, such as ankle foot orthoses for individuals with stroke and cerebral palsy. We also developed open-source tools to support device tuning for prosthetists and orthotists that can be used on any smartphone.

From an educational perspective, this award also supported undergraduate and graduate engineering students; training them in the unique skills required to design and evaluate assistive technology that can interface with the human body. Examples of undergraduate projects resulting from this research include our work to design affordable and customizable orthoses to support activities of daily living for individuals with spinal cord injury and extracurricular activities for children with disabilities. This award also supported Michael Rosenberg's PhD Dissertation on "Modeling and predicting response to ankle exoskeletons." We also founded and continue to support a student organization at the University of Washington that supports accessible design and play technology, HuskyADAPT. The students who participated in these research and educational experiences will bring the principles of inclusive design, accessibility, and disability studies they learned to their future engineering careers to help create more inclusive products, experiences, and environments.

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2022
Modified by: Katherine Steele

Images (1 of )
  • Physics-based musculoskeletal simulation can be used to predict changes in muscle activity with assistive devices like ankle foot orthoses. As an example, passive and powered orthoses reduced muscle activity during common crouch gait patterns in children with cerebral palsy.
    Steele Lab
    Copyrighted
    Katherine Steele
    Musculoskeletal Simulation of Ankle Foot Orthoses
  • Examples of three upper-extremity orthoses designed with 3D-printing. These devices use wrist and elbow flexion/extension to open and close the hand or a custom grasper.
    Steele Lab
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Katherine Steele
    Upper-Extremity Orthoses
  • Three different data-driven approaches were used to predict changes in kinematics and muscle activity when nondisabled adults walked with bilateral passive ankle exoskeletons.
    Steele Lab
    Copyrighted
    Katherine Steele
    Data-Driven Approaches to Predict Exoskeleton Responses
  • Muscle synergies can be used to quantify changes in muscle activity during in activity such as walking with an exoskeleton. Nondisabled adults altered their neuromuscular control patterns when walking with a powered exoskeletons, demonstrating increased complexity of control.
    Steele Lab
    Copyrighted
    Katherine Steele
    Changes in Neuromuscular Control with Exoskeletons
  • We used musculoskeletal simulations and experimental measures of kinematics and ultrasound of the musculotendon junction to evaluate muscle and tendon length of the gastrocnemius when walking with ankle foot orthoses of different stiffness levels.
    Steele Lab
    Copyrighted
    Katherine Steele
    Modeling & Ultrasound to Quantify Musculotendon Dynamics
  • A smartphone app that uses the inertial measurement unit in the phone to monitor tilt was developed and tested during gait to provide clinicians with a common measure used to customize the fit of prosthetic and orthotic devices.
    Steele Lab
    Copyrighted
    Katherine Steele
    Mobile App to Tune Orthoses
por.por_txt_cntn:
This NSF CAREER awarded supported integrated research, education, and outreach activities that sought to expand our understanding of how assistive technology can support and improve human movement. Specifically, we focused on how orthoses or exoskeletons - devices that can be worn on the body to augment an individual's movement - need to be customized based upon each individual's needs and abilities.
